Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Advancing State of the Art of Coding/Modulation for Wireless Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Wireless networking constitutes an important component of future information technology applications for both military and civilian purposes ranging from ad-hoc and sensor networks deployed in a battle-field to cellular networks with a very strong infrastructure. In order to design, implement and deploy highly reliable wireless networks, it is of utmost importance to address the presence of interference from other users in the system. In existing designs, interference is either avoided by a carefully chosen networking protocol (e.g. through time-division, space-division, frequency-division), or it is controlled to be near an acceptable level (e.g. through code-division). While simplifying the implementation, both of these commonly taken approaches are far from being optimal, and for reliable and efficient wireless networks of the future, a different look at the problem of handling the interference is needed.
This research aims to develop explicit and practical coding/modulation solutions for multi-user communication channels, and to assess the possible gains with the enhanced physical-layer designs through end-to-end network simulation studies. In particular, a number of problems ranging from design of coding/modulation schemes for wireless interference channels, and two-way relay channels, to practical signaling for finite-input finite-output multi-user links are addressed. Both long block length coding/modulation solutions aiming at near capacity (or capacity bound) operation as well as short block length designs for delay sensitive applications are explored. Through these research activities, the project directly contributes to design and development of reliable wireless networks managing interference in an efficient manner, and to the field of general multi-user communications in a fundamental way. The project also integrates research and education generating many opportunities for undergraduate students to be involved in these activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In order to design, implement and deploy highly reliable wireless networks, including ad-hoc or sensor networks, cellular networks, or even body area networks, it is of utmost importance to address the presence of interference. In most existing designs, interference is either avoided by a carefully chosen networking protocol (e.g., through time-division, space-division, frequency-division), or it is controlled to be near an acceptable level (e.g., through code-division). Both of these commonly taken approaches are far from being optimal, and for reliable and efficient wireless networks of the future, a different look at the problem of handling the interference is needed.

With this motivation, in this project we have dealt with explicit and implementable coding/modulation schemes for different multi-user communication scenarios. In particular, we have developed capacity (bound) approaching coding principles for wireless interference channels, signaling approaches for two-way relay channels for different scenarios, and new delay tolerant (short block length) channel codes for multi-user communication systems including multiple access and interference channels. We have also made advences in code design for multi-user communication set-ups including finite-input finite-output interference links which is of significant theoretical interest as stepping stones for more complicated and practical channel models.

We also note that this project has contributed significantly towards human resource development in the important field of information and communication technologies. Specifically, four PhD students have been supported during its course:

  • Mojtaba Rahmati (who was partially funded through this project) received his PhD in April 2013 from Arizona State University. His dissertation title is ``On Asynchronous Communication Systems: Capacity Bounds and Relaying Schemes.'' 
  • Shahrouz Sharifi (who was entirely funded through this project) received his PhD in September 2015 from Arizona State University. His dissertation title is ``On Code Design for Interference Channels.''
  • Ahmad Salim (who was mostly funded through this project) is expected to graduate with his PhD by December 2015. His thesis topic is ``Transmission Strategies for Two-Way Relay Channels.''
  • Ahmad ElMoslimany (who was partially funded through this project) is expected to graduate with his PhD by December 2015. His thesis topic is ``A New Communication Scheme for Underwater Acoustic Channels: System Design, Information Theoretic Analysis and Channel Coding.''

Finally, we note that our detailed findings through the project have been reported in cutting-edge journal and conference papers in leading journals and international conferences in the fields of information theory and communications.
